case_vignette: A 32-year-old male presents to his primary care physician. The patient has a history of hypertension, which was found to be the result of an adrenal mass. He is status post resection. On physical exam, vital signs are HR 78 bpm, BP 135/90 mmHg, RR 12 rpm, Sat 100%. Examination of the neck reveals a 2 cm firm, immobile, and nontender mass in the right inferior pole of the thyroid. Laboratory evaluation reveals normal TSH, PTH, and calcium. A biopsy of the lesion is obtained, with H&E staining shown in Figure A.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_0.summarized_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Medullary carcinoma based on the given symptoms and information. Adrenal masses causing hypertension are more commonly associated with pheochromocytomas or aldosterone-producing adenomas, but Medullary carcinoma of the adrenal gland can also present with hypertension. Medullary carcinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that can originate in the adrenal glands and produce various hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and calcitonin. Follicular and papillary thyroid carcinomas are more common in the thyroid gland and typically do not present with hypertension as a primary symptom. Lymphoma of the thyroid is also less likely given the absence of other symptoms and significant medical history.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Pheochromocytoma. This is a tumor of the adrenal gland that can cause high blood pressure by releasing excessive amounts of catecholamines.
